nrp 0.1.0.0
  • Reference

    nrp

    nrp is an R package that is being developed for the Nutrient Restoration Program (NRP). It currently provides the following functionality for CTD data:

    Read in raw data files
    The package checks the validity of input data, and references the the CTD site table in the database to ensure the correct SiteID is assigned for each file. the date and units are extracted from the file metadata, and any missing units are filled in.

    Upload data to the NRP SQLite database
    When uploading new data to the database, the package checks to ensure that no duplicate data is present, that values fall within acceptable ranges, and that units are correct.

    Download CTD data
    CTD data can be downloaded from the database with optional filtering by SiteID, date range, and parameter name. The CTD site table can also be downloaded from the database.

    Installation

    To install the latest development version from GitHub

    # install.packages("drat")
drat::addRepo("poissonconsulting")
devtools::install_github("poissonconsulting/nrp")

    Demonstration

    For simplicity, this demo uses an empty, temporary database to read and write to, and uses some test data that travels with the package.

    library(nrp)

# create empty database with automatically populated Site and Lake tables
# path = ":memory:" creates a temporory, in memory database
conn <- nrp_create_db(path = ":memory:", ask = FALSE) 

# provide a path to a .cnv file
path <-  system.file("extdata", "ctd/2018/KL1_27Aug2018008downcast.cnv",
                       package = "nrp", mustWork = TRUE)

# read in file
# function looks at the database site table to assign SiteID for each file
data <- nrp_read_ctd_file(path, db_path = conn)
#> 32 negative depths removed from data

data
#> # A tibble: 1,413 x 18
#>    FileID SiteID Date       Time  Depth Temperature Oxygen Oxygen2
#>     <int> <chr>  <date>     <tim> <S3:> <S3: units> <S3: > <S3: u>
#>  1      1 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.09… 17.4318 [d… 9.391… 98.081…
#>  2      2 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.19… 17.4351 [d… 9.289… 97.025…
#>  3      3 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.27… 17.4376 [d… 9.121… 95.273…
#>  4      4 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.32… 17.4393 [d… 8.911… 93.077…
#>  5      5 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.33… 17.4379 [d… 8.677… 90.631…
#>  6      6 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.29… 17.4121 [d… 8.443… 88.146…
#>  7      7 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.27… 17.3812 [d… 8.226… 85.822…
#>  8      8 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.26… 17.3667 [d… 8.042… 83.875…
#>  9      9 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.28… 17.3781 [d… 7.905… 82.469…
#> 10     10 KL1    2018-08-27 18:05 0.31… 17.3954 [d… 7.818… 81.588…
#> # … with 1,403 more rows, and 10 more variables: Conductivity <S3: units>,
#> #   Conductivity2 <S3: units>, Salinity <S3: units>, Backscatter <S3:
#> #   units>, Fluorescence <S3: units>, Frequency <S3: units>, Flag <dbl>,
#> #   Pressure <S3: units>, Retain <lgl>, File <chr>

# upload data to the database
nrp_upload_ctd(data = data, db_path = conn)
#> 131 duplicate depths removed from data

# download data from database, filtering by Date and SiteID
db_data <- nrp_download_ctd(start_date = "2018-08-27",
                            end_date = "2018-08-27",
                            sites = "KL1",
                            db_path = conn)
db_data
